The game is not without its flaws, it has frequently unfair stealth and for a good chunk of the game you do not know what the hell with a lot of things unless you go to a wiki. Nonetheless, it is an amazing gaming experience. The game is surprisingly varied, no situation overstays its welcome. Sometimes you are going stealthy, others you go full blast mode and sometimes you do not see a shootable enemy for a good amount of time, but none of these happen for too long. Once you get the hang of it, the game turns a challenging, mostly fair and rewarding experience.  With very little to no handholding, this a refreshing experience as a game in general.

Metro 2033 is a fine example of a cult classic. Metro 2033 may not do anything perticularly innovative it is a great example of how linear FPS's can provide a detailed and entertaining narrative experience.

Pros:
-Fantastic detail. Search around enough and you'll always find somewhere these people eat, sleep, trade and even poop.
-Strong narrative. A nice stroy with a few choices sprinkled along the way.
-Strong gunplay. You point and click, stuff dies - nice!
-Good stealth mechanics, stealth is almost always an option.
-Ranger modes. I highly recommend both ranger moders perticuarly ranger hardcore mode. They make combat leathal but    fair and it creates this organic shooter/stealth gameplay which most games cannot provide.
-Good graphics and audio.
-A great atmosphere. Both the towns, shootouts and horror elements all feel 'right'. They really nailed the atmosphere of the era and the book.

Cons:
-Linear. For those who hate corridors, stay away.
-Nothing that innovative. What there shines but it's nothing too new.
-Ranger Hardcore mode makes one part of the game close to impossible. You can change the difficultly on the fly and you'll probably have to for that one section (close to the end).

Overall great game - RECOMMENDED.
I would drag my wingding through eight kilometres of shattered windowpane to hear this game dilly-dallied through a remote walkie-talkie.

Metro 2033 is full of stunning detail and realism of a post-apocalyptic Moscow. Even on it's lower graphics settings, this game has magnificant detail. This game definitely has some stunning and scary moments. The easy difficulties give you a more relaxing way to look at the environment and settings, while the harder difficulties keep you on edge with harder-to-find ammunition and items.

This game took well off the novel of the same name. They did a great job. The only downsides are the once-in-a-while annoying glitches that every game has.

I definitely recommend this game.

reviewText:
To keep my Review short since its sort of like a triple A game:
Played the story, not that bad its a great game! Its a geat horror story, you`ll be fighting the mutated monsters and with that will be fighting the humans, of course. You will need to scavenge for ammo, which rewards you for exploring! The environment is detailed, and in the story you`ll be given decisions which you will have to make.
By the way it has 2 endings!
The only downside for me is that there is no multiplayer, the enemy AI could also be alittle problematic, honestly I did get lost but only once. Its a great game, but I recommend the Metro: Last Light over this one, once you`ve played that and you want more, come to the less refined editon.

A basic linear shooter loaded with a cavalcade of innovative, unique and ingenious ideas that are all tragically hampered by mediocre execution. Ammo as currency! Seamless stealth/action gameplay! Animal enemies that can be intimidated rather than fought! 100% diegetic interface! It's a shame that there's special currency ammo, stealth is so unforgiving, the animal AI is so dodgy, and that the game is awkward and unpolished in general. Even the great atmosphere, story and setting are let down by total (often literally on-rails) linearity, crap voice acting and inadequate exploration of the non-hostile elements of the Metro.

I'll start first by saying, before I played this, it had been a while since I found a game truly captivating. Dmitry Glukhovsky (The author of the book) has created a perfect atmosphere and environment, with points in which one truly values the existence of other people. With civilizations being far apart, one also feels that sense of insecurity whenever they are not within a civilization.

Despite the game being hugely linear, it makes up for it with immersion, atmosphere, story, detail and most, if not all aspects of the game. And, in saying it is a linear game, one is free to choose the how they'd like to take on the majority of battles, with a pleasing and sufficient array of weaponry to purchase and find.

It really is a flawless game for what it is, if it wasn't linear, it would come close to being my number 1 game. As it stands, it'll just have to settle for a favourite.

A really great game. Great story, great characters, the gunfights are intense and the world makes you feel like mankind is actually on the brink of extinction and your fighting for whats left of humanity. I must say it is rather difficult though, I actually had to turn the difficulty down because I was getting wrecked left and right, defintiely not the type of game where you can go sprinting around a corner with a shotty blowing away everyone around you. Tactics, patience, if your not ready to plan out your appraoch before dashing into battle then prepare to die A LOT.
A bit to long, but great. Really captured the mood of the books.

reviewText: Metro is one of the best FPS shooters I have played. The fact it has an interesting and intriging storyline is icing on the cake. The outcome of the game depends on the player's relationship with the environment and the people he or she encounters along the way. Kill or don't kill. Play a combinaton of stealth and gunner, or straight up one way or the other. Either way is challenging and did I mention fun! If you like FPS's with a great storyline Metro will keep you occupied for hours.\nTwo Ranger Modes up the challenge bar. So far I have half the Achievements, goal is to master the game.  Reading a review about it is great, but actually playing the game will plunge you into fun filled action.

reviewText:
So very, very immersive, you'll genuinely question if your loved ones are still alive. (Which, after finishing playing, I'd like to garuntee that they most probably are)

After reading the novel, I was skeptical about a game (the novel is less shoot-y, more think-y) but the immersion in the game is its chiefest quality by far. You could question the graphics, they are decent, even on lower qualities, but bear in mind that this wasn't a big studio budget game (even Last Light was 10% the budget of some of its competitors and look how well that did). The weapon animations and idle ones are, however, unique and (again) immersive.

The story isn't 100% faithful to the book I must add, but that's hardly a negative, it gives the same impression. That you (or your character, Artyom, unless you're so immersed that you've assumed his identity) are thrown from one event to the next, and by the time you've finished, you've realised that you've just completed one epic Odyssey across (and far below) Post-Apocalyptic Moscow.

PS. Look at my hours, that's genuine, it's rare you find such a good single player game.

reviewText: I started playing computer games around 1996 and I have to say that I rarely found a game so haunting, atmospheric and challenging as Metro 2033. On first glance one might think it´s all in confined space underground

I rarely had the impression in other games that the game was literally trying to kill me (my character). You are confronted with all kinds of enemies plus a deadly
recommended: deadly outside world. I give Metro 2033 a (rare) 10/10."

reviewText:
Metro 2033 was my first game I got on Steam. To be honest, I never knew what it is about - just heard a few things. Many years later now I thought that it's finally time to play it. That was a good choice but still, I wish I would decided to do it much earlier.

It was around beggining of autumn 2015. I'm glad I picked Metro 2033 to play during this season because for some reason it's the best time to play post-apocaliptic games, at least for me. While I wasn't so much curious about this game or the next one, once I started to play I get right into it. I felt how amazing Metro was. My first thought was it's kind of like Stalker games but sadly without open world. But I think it turned out to be good thing. I could say few things about graphics (it looks fantastic even many years after release), music, story or how great atmosphere this game have. To be honest, I would like only to say only something about Ranger mode. This is main reason why I enjoyed this game so much. Harder, but only because it's more realistic, and without any HUD you can enjoy Metro 2033 even more. It makes you think more serious about surviving in this cruel world, looking for other solutions that the obvious one. I wouldn't mind at all if it was replaced as normal game mode. This way more people who doesn't like to play a game few times could enjoy it too.

Too bad there is no option to buy this game anymore, since there is only Redux edition. Not sure if it's better but I heard only bad things about it, while compared to normal version of Metro 2033. Still, if you want to enjoy game with post-apocalyptic world, Metro 2033 (both this or Redux version) is great choice.

The game is not without its flaws, it has frequently unfair stealth and for a good chunk of the game you do not know what the hell with a lot of things unless you go to a wiki. Nonetheless, it is an amazing gaming experience. The game is surprisingly varied, no situation overstays its welcome. Sometimes you are going stealthy, others you go full blast mode and sometimes you do not see a shootable enemy for a good amount of time, but none of these happen for too long. Once you get the hang of it, the game turns a challenging, mostly fair and rewarding experience.  With very little to no handholding, this a refreshing experience as a game in general.

Metro 2033 is the current gen crysis. If you want to see just how far you can push your rig, this is the game to see. With directX 11 support, teselation, and extreme high resoultions & textures, this game will bend your pc over and buttrape it. Unless you hvae a 400 or 500 series nvidia card (not integrated) 50 or above, this is a waste of your time.  If you DO have good hardware however, this game is tons of fun! Making smoke come out of your GPU has never been soo rewarding! This game goes on sale a lot so don't purchase it at full price. Wait for it to hit 5$ (Happens fairly often).  It is the year 2033. The world has been destroyed by nuclear warfare! You play through the game in russia. Bullets are currency, everyone lives underground, gas masks are needed to hit up your buddy on the surface, and just living itself is dangerous. This game is a total warzone. Rival gangs, mutated creatures, & funny dialogue await you in this wonderful story. ~PR0XIDIAN

In my 29 Hours of playtime, I have played through the game twice on two difficulties, and it never gets old. It is insanely addicting to me. The struggle for ammo is real, and adds tension to the air by the second. Best last resort is your knife, I had to do this in the intro with Hunter because they only gave you like 10 or so bullets for your Revolver on Ranger Easy. (This was the second playthrough, mind you.) However, I've never broken a mask, so I can't tell you what that's like. I'm sure its terrifying.

If your a fan of post-apocalyptic games, this one is definitely for you. The main currency of the game are old Military-Grade rounds, for God's sake. The patchwork of the weapons early on sell it even more. I swear, the Double-Barrel is made of tin cans.

I'm looking forward to playing Metro: Last Light for this Christmas. Oh, and if you are planning to get this game, I highly recommend getting the Redux Edition. All sorts of new goodies that the original doesn't have.

reviewText: Atmospheric oozing, the only downfall to this juicy survival FPS is the many references to the book and staying true to it's origins was definitely inspired by the predecessor in the genre: Skyrim 4. - 10/10
Атмосферный шутан, книжка получше

I haven't played such a great singleplayer FPS in a long time. It's based off a novel so already the storyline and atmosphere is there. The pacing is really good: one minute you're sneaking through a dark settlement silently taking down bandits (or guns blazing if you prefer to play that way), next you're riding shotgun on a train down some tracks, then just as you want a change of pace you're sent to explore a creepy cave with your guide telling you more about what's going on in the world. Fantastic.\n\nGreat storyline, settings and atmosphere is superb. Some original gameplay elements such as needing to collect filters for your gas mask, using ammo as currency and even being able to choose how to respond to people in some of the story events. Seriously good FPS game, well worth the 12 hours or so.
One of the best Games!!

WHAT A DEAL!!! I got this game when it was free on Humble Bundle and WOW! from the first moment you are pulled into the game like a Gravitational Anomaly in S.T.AL.K.E.R. In the first half an hour of gameplay you will be down to your last bullet (Which you are almost certain to miss since your adrenaline is near cardiac arrest levels) and desperatly searching for new gas filters for your mask, or a new mask for that matter because the one you are wearing is broken. This game has a great storyline that leaves you hungry for more when the credits start rolling.

The thing I think that should be crucial for any survival game is being forced to not only take down beast more powerful than you, but the need to make every shot count while you do it. This game does that. Before long you will be making sure every shotgun pellet hits that mutants face. You try as hard as you can to hold on to any military grade bullet you have since it is the primary currency in the game (One high quality 5.45mm round for five low quality, or two 12 guage, as well as new weapons and other supplies). The homemade style of a lot of the weapons is like icing on top of a cake. The attention to detail is fantastic.

For me the only drawback in this game the Protagonist Artyoms voice over is a bit flat in the cutscenes, at least in the english version anyway. There isn't anything else I could fault with this game.

9/10 This is a must have so don't hesitate.
May not be the most open world shooter, but it's fun as all hell. Gives you a feeling of isolation whether you're in the metro, or on the uninhabitable surface. Looking forward to the sequel!

reviewText:
So very, very immersive, you'll genuinely question if your loved ones are still alive. (Which, after finishing playing, I'd like to garuntee that they most probably are)

After reading the novel, I was skeptical about a game (the novel is less shoot-y, more think-y) but the immersion in the game is its chiefest quality by far. You could question the graphics, they are decent, even on lower qualities, but bear in mind that this wasn't a big studio budget game (even Last Light was 10% the budget of some of its competitors and look how well that did). The weapon animations and idle ones are, however, unique and (again) immersive.

The story isn't 100% faithful to the book I must add, but that's hardly a negative, it gives the same impression. That you (or your character, Artyom, unless you're so immersed that you've assumed his identity) are thrown from one event to the next, and by the time you've finished, you've realised that you've just completed one epic Odyssey across (and far below) Post-Apocalyptic Moscow.

PS. Look at my hours, that's genuine, it's rare you find such a good single player game.

reviewText:
Metro 2033 was my first game I got on Steam. To be honest, I never knew what it is about - just heard a few things. Many years later now I thought that it's finally time to play it. That was a good choice but still, I wish I would decided to do it much earlier.

It was around beggining of autumn 2015. I'm glad I picked Metro 2033 to play during this season because for some reason it's the best time to play post-apocaliptic games, at least for me. While I wasn't so much curious about this game or the next one, once I started to play I get right into it. I felt how amazing Metro was. My first thought was it's kind of like Stalker games but sadly without open world. But I think it turned out to be good thing. I could say few things about graphics (it looks fantastic even many years after release), music, story or how great atmosphere this game have. To be honest, I would like only to say only something about Ranger mode. This is main reason why I enjoyed this game so much. Harder, but only because it's more realistic, and without any HUD you can enjoy Metro 2033 even more. It makes you think more serious about surviving in this cruel world, looking for other solutions that the obvious one. I wouldn't mind at all if it was replaced as normal game mode. This way more people who doesn't like to play a game few times could enjoy it too.

Too bad there is no option to buy this game anymore, since there is only Redux edition. Not sure if it's better but I heard only bad things about it, while compared to normal version of Metro 2033. Still, if you want to enjoy game with post-apocalyptic world, Metro 2033 (both this or Redux version) is great choice.

reviewText: A cracking first-person shooter. Superb atmosphere, amazing graphics, rich environments. Its a real pleasure exploring the Russian subway system and the post apocalyptic wasteland the game is set in. Up there with the Half-Lifes and the Bioshocks.

I rather enjoy this one because it's very dark and is good at painting a very depressing and very immersive picture of a ruinous future. One other thing I also loved is that the weapons are entirely balanced against themselves, something most FPS based games fail to achieve. If you like the revolver you got at the start of the game? It packs enough of a punch to be useful all the way to  the very end of the game.\n\nMy only real complaints are that ammo for the Tihar is too rare and any subtelty that it had established before goes right out the window on the last act of the game. It's all action all the time. That having been said, it's still great and I highly recommend it.
This isn't just a game... this is an experience. I love this game. I am addicted to it. This game makes you think my god this is deep." When you meet Khan

i have played a lot of survival games, i've played a lot of fps's.  i've played tons of them.  this is one of the few i have true feelings for.   if you haven't played this.  give it a run.  its a story, its immersive, its believeable, and is non stop thrills.  at 15 bucks, you're really getting a lot.

you'll enjoy metro.  also check out the stalker games.  decent stuff.  just stay away from stalker open skies or whatever its called, get stalker call of chernobyl and stalker call of pripyat.  and this one.  you'll enjoy them.  they have a very authenthic russian feel.  all three, this one and those two as well.

metro itself still has decent graphics.  they wont bug you too much and dont look too ugly.  the story makes sense from an post apoc sense.  the big bombs fell and everyone took shelter into the metro.. which is literally one of the doomsday scenarios, and something people in beriln did during the bombings there.  so.. legit.

the story feels real.  the characters do too.  you will experience loss in this game, and every time it stings.  you get to know these people, and you bleed with them.  the feeling of comraderie is strong.

one of the things i really like about the game is its immersiveness.  you'll feel it too once you start playing.
the music is pretty good too.

if you want a better graphical representation they redid them.  they're every bit as good but better graphics.

give this and the stalker series (not clear sky) a try.  you'll enjoy it.

I recieved my copy for free, so perhaps I shouldn't be harsh at all with it. But to others, it may come as a giant waste of time. I think if you buy it, you need to stay dedicated to it, and appreciate it for what it gives you. I also heard that Metro Last Light (the sequel) is better and I assume the Metro Redux that was made fixes those glitches, so you should probably just purchase the redux instead of the older version. This is one of the best games I've ever played, atmospherically. If you've ever wondered what living in a post-apocalyptic world was like, this game captures it amazingly. Gameplay is intense and rewarding, if not uncompromising. You'll get the feeling you're fighting for your survival at every moment. Everything about this game is both grim and beautiful. You can feel the ragged hope in the metro stations, the relentless misery of the torn, blasted city above ground, and everything in between. From bandits to monsters, mutants to soldiers, and even ghosts and phenomena to the despair of life in the Metro, it will make you realize one thing: we can't relinquish the things that make us human.
Great Game

Revisiting: Metro 2033

Original recommendation: A strange mix of Survival Horror and First Person Shooter, Metro 2033 is a well-scripted shooter in a highly atmospheric post apocalyptic world. The story is a little short, but full of shocking moments and fast-paced shooting. You're constantly encountering new factions, discovering interesting new locations, or being tasked to do something you haven't done before. Providing your system is capable, you'll be treated to a gorgeous experience which will make the game all the more immersive and fun to play.

The story: In 2033, Artyom, a 20-year-old survivor and one of the first-born in the metro, learns from an elite soldier, named Hunter that a group of mysterious creatures referred to as the Dark Ones are threatening his station in the Metro.
Having not read the source material, I can't say how faithfully it's adapted, however I can say its a great story with a surprising ending(s).

Presentation: Graphics are as good as they come: beautiful environments with a surprising amount of detail and fantastic animations. As for audio, the english voice acting is pretty poor, the guns don’t sound particularly powerful, but the monster noises will leave you quivering in fear.

Gameplay: For a first person shooter, there is actually surprisingly little shooting. There are some heavy action scenes and fights for survival against hordes of mutants, yet they are just one part of the game. The stealth aspect part is done fairly well - you can shoot or turn off most light sources and sneaking past everyone is sometimes a valid strategy. To top things off, there are also a couple of vehicle sections and the ability to upgrade your equipment by scavenging or buying better weapons.
In order to experience everything this game has to offer I recommend playing on ranger difficulty, with no crosshair and russian audio with your preferred subtitle option.

Graphics: 10
Sound: 7 (9 with russian audio)
Gameplay: 8
Story: 9
Multiplayer: N/A

Overall: 8.5/10

This is the most atmospheric game I have ever played. I recommend this to all the stalkers.\nEverything in this game is brilliant. I hated this game when I first played it. I didn't like how dark it was all the time (I know that's silly because it's set in a metro but I still hated it), I thought it was needlessly complicated and so on. I don't think I made it past level 1 before uninstalling. About a year later I gave it another try and forced myself to play for at least a couple of hours and I realized that I absolutely loved it. It is one of the scariest games I have ever played and on ranger hardcore mode it is very very challenging - you have to think about each step you take carefully because you die QUICKLY and ammunition and other supplies are scarce. It is very immersive and the immense graphics add to this massively. The lighting and shadows too are amazing. When you have to go outside you need to make sure you carry filters for your gas mask and if you run out you're dead, unless you can run inside very quickly, which you won't be able to unless you're right at the end of the level. There isn't too much exploration to be found, but there is some and it is rewarded with precious ammunition and other supplies.\n\nFor balance I will mention a few things I don't like. Stealth is broken. Sometimes it works, other times if one single enemy is alerted to your presence then every single enemy on the level will know where you are forever. Also they sometimes see you even if you're hiding in total darkness, even if they don't have a flashlight or night vision equipment. Another thing that annoyed me was how good and bad ammunition looks so alike you often can't tell what you're firing. In this game clean" ammunition is currency
date: you buy stuff with it and sell stuff for it. It's like money. "Dirty" ammunition is ammunition that is made by metro inhabitants. It does less damage but you get more of it
recommended: so you want to use as much dirty ammunition as possible and keep your clean ammunition to buy supplies (except in emergencies where you have to load clean ammunition in to your gun because you're out of dirty ammo). The problem is that the levels are so dark you often accidentally fire all of your clean ammo without realizing it because they look pretty much the same. This isn't a problem if you play on easy mode because the HUD tells you what you're firing
hoursPlayed: but on hard or ranger modes you have no HUD at all.\n\nOverall though this is a fantastic game and MUCH better than the sequel."

reviewText: Best SP Game EVER
Good and cheap scary shooting game!.\nGraphics is great and story are super.\nIts a must have in the collection for the price!.

10/10
The comparisons between the Metro and S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series are often, and rightly, made. Metro is very much the slick, story-channeled sibling of the more free-roaming S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games. Both are brilliant, and I am unashamedly and irretrievably biased towards both. Metro 2033 shows just how open-world a channelled game can feel when it is honed with artistry and innovation at every turn. Story is always central to the Metro games. However, I never once felt I was being moved on too speedily, or claustrophobically led through the story.

The inventory system - or lack thereof - was an irritation at first. This did not last, however.  (Here I should mention that, as with Last Light, I only played the game on Ranger mode, which apparently has a more limited UI than the standard mode of the game). The weapons in 2033 have a wealth of character and personality, making an inventory UI all but unnecessary. The way ammo is handled, however, could be improved upon. Pre-war ammo can be used as currency as well as ammunition, and is only distinguished by a slightly brighter icon. Several times I found myself firing this currency inadvertently.

The characters are rich and real; at times they took and left the stage too speedily, but never so fast as to fail to make an impact. I ended the game with a clear memory of the characters as a distinct and tangible cast. The larger narrative too is one that manages to surprise and move the player.

With the graphics set to high, this game will challenge the most advanced gaming PCs. I found 2033 stressed my rig more than Last Light, in fact. The work is warranted - textures are deep and detailed. Even in dimly lit passages, lighting is applied with skill and balance.
This is a brilliant game. One of my favorite things is that it does not take place in the USA. Gameplay: Awesome. Story: Even if it had some twist and tirnes away from the book its still good.

reviewText:
NOTE:  There is a remastered version of this game on the Steam store called Metro 2033 Redux, this review is for the original, not that one.

_______________________________________________________________________________

Metro 2033 is a very well made game with a very memorable story to boot and graphics that really rocked for the time the game was released, and still look pretty damn good today.

You play as the Russian Artyom, in the year 2033, well after a nuclear winter has destroyed the surface world of Earth and the people of Russia have been forced underground to live in the metro tunnels due to how inhabitable the surface became.

This is all to mention nothing of the creatures that now lurk the Earth.  Moscow is now home to what it's people call Nosalises, Demons (♥♥♥♥♥es" if your name is Bourbon)
date: Librarians and more.  These are mutated
recommended: radiated and otherwise newly created/modified/evolved creatures that apparently aren't fond of humans.  The Nosalises are similar to large mutated mole-dogs with variants of many types ranging from flying to a rhino variant.  The Demons are large flying creatures
hoursPlayed: resembling a cross with a bat/gargoyle and possible tiger.  The Librarians are the real threat here; Large
votesHelpful: gorilla-looking beast that likes to snort around and bare their teeth.  The developers did an amazing job with bringing these creatures to life in this game
votesTotal: and really letting the player know that they aren't to be trifled with.  The general lack of ammo and medkits
votesFunny: coupled with the available frequency of encountering some of these creatures really makes you start to respect the game atmosphere and possibly cause to you be more cautious when navigating the game world to avoid certain death when you're low on ammo.\n\nThis game runs on ammunition.  Ammunition is the currency of the game world
commentsCount: as well as your primary source of self-defense (provided you have something to shoot the bullet out of).  The developers really did a great job of making the ammunition just hard enough to find on any difficulty that most players will be required to start thinking of how much they have
column16: how much they're using and what weapons would be best to use.  They also implemented some really cool weapons in the game
column17: such as the ghetto-rigged ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ gun
column18: which is really only good at overheating itself and using up ammo
column19: but you'll likely encounter a time when it's all you got.\n\nThe characters in the game develop well and you can actually get to know some of them and develop a relationship/attachment to them.  They all have unique personalities
column20: even down to their names.  The game spends a lot of time trying to get you acquainted with the different characters
column21:
and does a great job of it.


The graphics and sound are very well done.  The graphics
column23: can still give newer hardware a bit of trouble due to the un-optimization of the game I believe.  The world design is great
column24: especially the moment you first step foot outside of the metro and see Moscow in the aftermath of the nuclear fallout with a Demon flying above crumbling gray buildings
column25: Nosalises running across things and your gas mask glaring and frosting up.\n\nThis game is one of my favorites and very underrated for what it is.  I certainly recommend this game."

Loved the game. Then I read the book! As I read I could hear the creepy, wet creaking of the tunnels I had crawled and run through while playing the game. The ideas presented in the book added depth to my understanding of the bleak world I had fought my way through and made me keen to experience the alternate endings.\nThese games present one of the most credible apocalyptic futures I have experienced. I felt immersed in the world that kept trying to kill me. Metro: Last Light was especially satisfying when I was able to address Artyom's anguish as he realised what he was destroying in the final moments of the novel.\nThe Metro games ask us to think about the way we approach the concept of us" and "them". Is it a default setting that causes humans to fear the "other"?"
Excellent game! Highly underrated, too

reviewText: Metro 2033 is a really good Post-apocalyptic/horror game. Even though this game came out in 2010 is still looks good for its age. The atmosphere, the story and the gameplay was really good. This is the first game that made me save every bullet i can. The only problem i have with this game is that it's not optimized that well, but i got lucky and didn't encounter that many problems. So if i would have to give this game a rating it would be a 9/10

Metro is fantastic, and way to live there is very interesting. Good optimalisation, raw, moody graphics, creepy sounds, every character has own story. First time I've heard Geiger's counter I nearly ♥♥♥♥ my pants. I really admire Artyom for his bravery and strenght. Awesome game, but short...\nAnd remember:\nIf it's hostile
If you're checking the reviews here wondering if the Redux edition is worth the extra cash...  It is.\nGo buy it!\n9/10

10/10, unforgettable experience and actually has replay value.\nAlthough the storyline in itself isn't much unless you've read the book, the atmosphere more than makes up for this.\nDefinitely recommend trying Russian audio with English subs, makes the immersion so much better.
Great singleplayer fps with loads of atmosphere, well scripted and some good set-pieces. Only the odd difficulty spike mars this game.
One of the best survival-horror/shooter that I've ever played - the atmosphere is depressingly beautiful and the gameplay is exciting and fresh.

The idea of being forced to live in the metro of post apocalyptic Moscow was what got me hooked into the game. Once I started to play it the my experience just got better and better. I enjoyed the different weapons and gear your character could have. You also had to be careful with ammo, or else you'll find yourself in a tight situation. The game does a great job in making you have to work hard and think smart in surviving. I didn't really pay attention to graphics because it should be the story that counts, and the story was amazing. This game is perfect for anyone who enjoys a FPS with horror and adventure aspects. I hope that you have as much fun as I did when I played this game.

i have played a lot of survival games, i've played a lot of fps's.  i've played tons of them.  this is one of the few i have true feelings for.   if you haven't played this.  give it a run.  its a story, its immersive, its believeable, and is non stop thrills.  at 15 bucks, you're really getting a lot.

you'll enjoy metro.  also check out the stalker games.  decent stuff.  just stay away from stalker open skies or whatever its called, get stalker call of chernobyl and stalker call of pripyat.  and this one.  you'll enjoy them.  they have a very authenthic russian feel.  all three, this one and those two as well.

metro itself still has decent graphics.  they wont bug you too much and dont look too ugly.  the story makes sense from an post apoc sense.  the big bombs fell and everyone took shelter into the metro.. which is literally one of the doomsday scenarios, and something people in beriln did during the bombings there.  so.. legit.

the story feels real.  the characters do too.  you will experience loss in this game, and every time it stings.  you get to know these people, and you bleed with them.  the feeling of comraderie is strong.

one of the things i really like about the game is its immersiveness.  you'll feel it too once you start playing.
the music is pretty good too.

if you want a better graphical representation they redid them.  they're every bit as good but better graphics.

give this and the stalker series (not clear sky) a try.  you'll enjoy it.
